makers.displaydate: 1931–2022; born Providence, RI; died Florida; active Orbisonia, PA and New York, NY
makers.displaymaker: Lee Bontecou, 1931–2022; born Providence, RI; died Florida; active Orbisonia, PA and New York, NY

texts.textentryhtml: The work of Lee Bontecou represents one of the most striking artistic responses to the pervasive anxiety of the 1950s, a moment when the space race and the rhetoric of nuclear confrontation reached a fevered pitch. While in Rome on a Fulbright scholarship in 1956 and 1958, Bontecou began using state-of-the-art industrial tools to create that most elemental of artistic media: drawing. To make Untitled, she aimed a portable acetylene torch at a piece of paper, reducing its oxygen flow to release thick layers of soot onto the support, which she exposed through successive acts of erasure and scraping. The result is haunting and altogether disconcerting.

Bontecou’s soot drawings were made in response to the pervasive anxieties of the Cold War, a moment when the space race and the rhetoric of nuclear confrontation reached a fevered pitch. While studying in Rome  on a Fulbright scholarship in 1957–58, Bontecou began “drawing” with industrial tools, discovering that when she shut off a welding torch’s oxygen supply, a low temperature flame was produced, one that does not ignite  piece of paper. Instead, the flame generates copious amounts of carbon-based powder, leaving deposits of soot on the paper’s surface. Bontecou then dug into, erased, and removed these particles with brushes, razor blades, and even her fingertips, creating, as the artist states, “a real black that one could sink into or enter.” The resulting image invites us to consider the environmental and physical repercussions of technological and scientific progress.
Leo Castelli Gallery, New York; Dr. Alvin E. Friedman Kien, New York.;
